<summary>
• The paper introduces the concept of shower partons and their distributions to describe hadron production at intermediate transverse momentum in high-energy nuclear collisions, where recombination of partons is more appropriate than fragmentation.
• The shower parton distributions (spd s) are determined phenomenologically from fragmentation functions (ff s) using a recombination model, which is key to linking shower partons to observed hadrons.
• The spd s are shown to be important in heavy-ion collisions due to the presence of thermal partons in the environment, which significantly affect the hadronization process.
• The paper demonstrates the utility of spd s in studying dihadron correlations and the interaction between a jet and its surrounding medium, which are not adequately described by ff s alone.
• The spd s are found to be useful in problems where the interaction between a jet and its environment or between particles within a jet cannot be ignored.
• The paper suggests that the spd s may need their own evolutionary process, similar to the ff s, to fully understand their behavior at different energy scales.
• The authors acknowledge the support of the U.S. Department of Energy and the Ministry of Education of China for their contributions to the research.
• The paper concludes that the basic hadronization process is recombination, and the spd s are essential for a universal description of hadron production across all transverse momentum scales.
• The authors express gratitude to S. Kretzer for helpful communication.
• The research was partially supported by grants from the U.S. Department of Energy and the Ministry of Education of China.
• The paper emphasizes the need for further investigation into the @xmath1 evolution of the spd s.
• The authors propose that the spd s can be extended to higher @xmath2 ranges by considering recombination of hard partons from overlapping jets at the LHC.
</summary>

<summary>
* The paper presents a new iterative method for solving nonconvex semidefinite programming problems with matrix-valued mapping inequality constraints, focusing on static output feedback controller design.
* The method approximates the nonconvex feasible set by a sequence of inner positive semidefinite convex approximation sets, generalizing previous approaches.
* The algorithm is simple to implement, requiring no globalization strategy like line search, and relies on standard semidefinite programming software tools.
* Convergence to a stationary point is proven under mild conditions, with the method being applicable to strongly convex functions.
* The paper introduces a regularization technique to ensure strict descent during the iterative process.
* Two methods for overestimating bilinear matrix-valued mappings are provided, with applications demonstrated in static output feedback control problems.
* Numerical tests using the COMPASS library are presented, comparing the new method with the convex-concave decomposition method.
* The method is shown to be effective for sparse linear static output feedback controller design, spectral abscissa optimization, and mixed @xmath0-norm synthesis optimization problems.
* The paper suggests that the method can be extended to more general nonconvex SDP problems by finding appropriate inner psd-convex approximations.
* Future research directions include extending the method to more general nonconvex SDP problems and further exploring applications in control design.
* The paper concludes by emphasizing the simplicity and effectiveness of the proposed method for solving nonconvex semidefinite programming problems in static output feedback controller design.
</summary>

• The paper discusses a discrete differential geometry scheme for the Dirac-Kähler formulation of fermionic field theory, aiming to maintain locality and continuum limit properties.

• The authors extend a proposal by Adams, using two parallel lattices to describe chiral symmetry and exact flavor projection in the Dirac-Kähler formulation, introducing new structures and operators.

• They demonstrate that exact chiral and flavor projection necessitates the introduction of two new complexes and a new operator, and that simultaneous chiral and flavor projection requires careful definition to avoid mixing chiralities.

• The paper evaluates the path integral for the formulation, showing that the correct continuum limit is achieved with the introduction of a specific constant, and that the form of the path integral on each complex, prior to flavor projection, is equivalent to that used in the quarter-root trick of lattice QCD.

• The paper investigates collaborative relay beamforming in cognitive radio networks under secrecy constraints, formulating the problem as a quasiconvex optimization problem solvable by convex semidefinite programming (SDP). Two sub-optimal null space beamforming schemes are proposed to reduce computational complexity. Numerical results demonstrate that null space beamforming schemes achieve rates close to optimal ones, especially at high signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs).

• The paper extends the analysis to scenarios with multiple primary users and eavesdroppers, showing that null space beamforming can still be effective under certain conditions. The performance of beamforming schemes is illustrated through simulations, demonstrating the effectiveness of null space beamforming in maintaining high secrecy rates even when channels to eavesdroppers are stronger on average than those to the destination.

<summary>
• The paper demonstrates the advantages of preserving the @xmath0 invariance when quantizing the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFS), using Dirac's six-cone formalism and the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme.
• It introduces auxiliary fields to handle gauge freedom and maintains the @xmath0 symmetry throughout the quantization process, resulting in a set of Wightman two-point functions that are Minkowskian in form.
• The paper extends the results to general CFS and shows that the classical and quantum structures of the free Maxwell field are locally the same in all conformally flat spaces, with the same implications for other free fields and @xmath0-invariant interactions.
</summary>

<summary>
• The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs where vertices fire chips to neighbors if possible, with a finite number of positions and periods.
• The minimal number of steps for a position to repeat is its period, and the minimal number of steps for all positions to reach a repeating state is the transient length.
• The complete bipartite graph has only periods of length 1 or 2, and all connected graphs have a period of 1.
• Every possible period for the complete bipartite graph is characterized, and positions with all such periods are constructed.
• The parallel chip-firing game has connections to various fields, including number theory, algebra, combinatorics, and physics, and can simulate classical computers and physical phenomena like the deterministic fixed-energy sandpile.
• Further research directions include bounding period lengths on vertex-regular graphs, studying transient positions, and reducing the game by removing chips without changing firing patterns.
</summary>

• Grb 090510 is analyzed as a short gamma-ray burst (s-grb) originating from a binary neutron star (ns) merger, providing evidence for the formation of a black hole (bh).
• The analysis includes a new time-resolved spectral analysis, identifying a sequence of events: p-grb, prompt emission, and high-energy (GeV) emission linked to bh formation.
• The p-grb spectrum is best fitted by a comptonized component interpreted as a convolution of thermal spectra from a dyadotorus, indicating the presence of a rotating bh.
• The prompt emission analysis reveals the structure of the circumburst medium, with an average density typical of galactic halos.
• The delayed GeV emission, following the p-grb, is consistent with accretion onto a newly-formed bh and is one of the most intense observed in any s-grb.
• The analysis confirms the presence of a rotating bh, with the energy requirement for the GeV emission fulfilled by the accretion of crustal material from a binary ns progenitor.
• The cosmological redshift of the source is estimated to be consistent with the observed value, supporting the theoretical model.
• The study provides a deeper understanding of the formation process of a bh and the jetted GeV emission observed in various systems with a kerr bh.
• The work utilized data from the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope and Swift satellites, along with optical observations from VLT/FORS2 and Nordic Optical Telescope.
• The research contributes to the classification of s-grbs and bdhne, expanding the understanding of the diverse progenitors and physical processes associated with these high-energy astrophysical events.

• The renormalization of models with new physics at tree level often requires additional input parameters beyond those in the standard model ( sm ) , which can lead to incorrect conclusions about the decoupling of new physics at high scales.
• In models with a real scalar triplet higgs boson, the scalar mass dependence in the radiative corrections to the @xmath0 parameter becomes logarithmic, not quadratic as in the sm.
• The triplet higgs boson is non-decoupling, meaning that even a small triplet vev can contribute to the @xmath0 parameter, preventing the sm from being recovered at one loop.
• The presence of a triplet higgs boson allows for a heavier neutral higgs boson than is allowed in the sm, as cancellations between scalar contributions can occur.
• The left-right symmetric model also exhibits non-decoupling, but with a different mechanism, where the scalar mass dependence in the radiative corrections is also logarithmic.
• Proper renormalization schemes are crucial for accurately predicting the behavior of electroweak observables in models with new physics beyond the sm.

<summary>• A log-Riemann surface is a pair consisting of a compact Riemann surface and a local holomorphic diffeomorphism to the Riemann sphere, with a discrete set of points added in the completion with respect to the path metric induced by the flat metric.
• Log-Riemann surfaces of finite type are given by certain transcendental functions with exponential singularities at a finite set of punctures, and are equivalent to covering spaces of the Riemann sphere by punctured discs or half-planes.
• The main theorem establishes a one-to-one correspondence between exp-algebraic curves and degree zero line bundles on a compact Riemann surface with meromorphic connections, preserving divisors.

• The paper presents a computationally efficient method to interpolate self-energies for a range of dopings, degeneracies, and interactions in strongly correlated electronic systems, using constraints from the slave boson mean field method and the functional form of the atomic green function.
• The proposed interpolative approach yields results in remarkable agreement with quantum Monte Carlo simulations across a wide range of parameters, with some residual discrepancies that can be corrected by refining the constraints or implementing more sophisticated impurity solvers.
• The method offers a significant computational speed advantage over quantum Monte Carlo, making it suitable for exploring the entire parameter space necessary for simulating real materials, and it can be extended for improved accuracy by incorporating additional constraints and refined impurity solvers.

• The study investigates the impact of inert sites on the phase transitions of the surface reaction model (zgb model) relevant to catalytic surface oxidation processes.
• The zgb model is modified to include a random distribution of inert sites on the catalytic surface, affecting the adsorption and reaction of reactants.
• Mean-field and pair approximation calculations, along with monte carlo simulations, are used to determine the phase diagram and the transition lines as functions of the concentration of inert sites.
• The transition between active and poisoned states is found to be of the first-order type for all values of inert site concentration in the approximations, but becomes continuous in simulations at a critical concentration.
• The production rate of the reaction product is maximum at the first-order transition in both approximations, but the nature of the transition changes in simulations at the critical concentration of inert sites.
• The study concludes that inert sites reduce the production of reaction products by blocking reactions over the catalyst and by shifting the phase boundary towards a reactive window.

<summary>
• The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems on crystal lattices, extending problems from Euclidean lattices to spaces with geometric structures.
• The crystal lattice is defined as an infinite graph with a free abelian group action, and the paper constructs a scaling limit using discrete harmonic maps.
• The main focus is on the symmetric simple exclusion process and its perturbation, the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process, on the crystal lattice.
• The paper formulates a replacement theorem using @xmath2-periodic local function bundles and proves it via a super exponential estimate, which is crucial for the proof.
• The local ergodic theorem is modified to handle the local inhomogeneity of the crystal lattice, and it is proven using a super exponential estimate.
• The paper establishes the convergence of the combinatorial Laplacian on the scaled discrete torus to the Laplacian on the torus, which is essential for the hydrodynamic limit.
• The proof of the main theorem involves the one-block and two-block estimates, which are shown to hold for @xmath2-periodic local function bundles.
• The main theorem states that the empirical density of the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process on the crystal lattice converges to a solution of a quasi-linear parabolic equation with diffusion and nonlinear drift terms.
• The paper also discusses the implications of the results for interacting particle systems in random environments and the hydrodynamic limit on spaces with topological defects.
• The paper's approach could be applied to more general random graphs, potentially impacting material sciences and the study of systems with topological defects.
• The paper includes an appendix with proofs of related lemmas and an energy estimate for the weak solution of the partial differential equation.
• The authors mention related works on the hydrodynamic limit for other lattices and systems, indicating the broader context of their research.
• The paper is organized with sections on crystal lattices, the hydrodynamic limit, the replacement theorem, and the proof of the main theorem, along with appendices for additional technical details.
• The paper concludes by emphasizing the significance of the results for understanding the macroscopic behavior of particles in relation to the geometric structures of the underlying spaces.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study of harmonic maps, critical points of the energy functional, was initiated by F.B. Fuller, J. Nash, and J.H. Sampson.
• Harmonic maps between pseudo-Riemannian manifolds have distinct behaviors and are subject to restricted classes of manifolds.
• The paper defines and studies paraholomorphic maps between almost para-Hermitian and para-Sasakian manifolds, proving that the tension field of any such map lies in a specific space.
• The paper also defines and studies parapluriharmonic maps between para-Sasakian and pseudo-Riemannian manifolds, providing necessary and sufficient conditions for a map to be @xmath0-parapluriharmonic.
• An almost product structure on a manifold is defined, and the paper explores the conditions under which a manifold with a triplet structure is para-Khler, para-contact, or para-Sasakian.
• The paper proves that a @xmath1-paraholomorphic map between para-Sasakian manifolds is harmonic and that a @xmath2-paraholomorphic map between an almost para-Hermitian manifold and a para-Sasakian manifold is @xmath3-parapluriharmonic.
• The paper concludes with a corollary stating that a @xmath4-parapluriharmonic map between certain manifolds is paracosymplectic.
• The paper also discusses the implications of harmonic maps in various fields such as computational fluid dynamics, minimal surface theory, string theory, gravity, and quantum field theory.
• The paper includes a detailed mathematical exposition with numerous equations and propositions, demonstrating the complex nature of the study of harmonic maps in the context of pseudo-Riemannian geometry.
• The paper references previous works and acknowledges the contributions of other researchers in the field.
• The paper is structured into sections, each focusing on different aspects of harmonic maps and their applications.
• The paper concludes with a proof of a main theorem and several corollaries and propositions related to the main theorem.
• The paper is part of a larger work on harmonic mappings, twistors, and @xmath5-models, indicating its relevance to

• The star formation rate ( SFR) of galaxies is crucial for understanding the universe's hierarchical build-up, but unregulated star formation leads to an overabundance of high-mass galaxies, suggesting a quenching mechanism is needed.
• Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in massive galaxies are thought to regulate star formation through feedback processes, but the exact mechanism remains debated.
• Infrared (IR) observations are key to studying star formation in active galactic nucleus (AGN) host galaxies, as dust re-emits stellar light from young stars, providing insights into the current SFR.
• Dust obscures our view of AGN, but recent Herschel data have expanded our knowledge of the far-infrared (FIR) properties of AGN host galaxies, crucial for estimating SFR.
• A sample of 313 AGN was selected using ultra-hard X-ray observations and imaged with the Herschel Space Observatory's Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver (SPIRE), focusing on moderate luminosity Seyfert galaxies (Seyfert 1-2).
• The study found that while the overall FIR luminosity distributions of AGN host galaxies are similar to those of normal star-forming galaxies, there are some differences, such as a weak correlation between FIR luminosity and ultra-hard X-ray luminosity for Seyfert 1 galaxies only.
• Anomalous colors in six AGN suggest synchrotron emission from radio jets rather than thermal dust emission, indicating a different heating source for these AGN.
• The study also found a weak correlation between Seyfert 1 AGN luminosity and radio loudness, but not for Seyfert 2 AGN, hinting at a possible link between star formation and AGN activity at high luminosities.
• The study speculates that the excess emission at 500 micrometers in some AGN could be related to radio emission from the accretion disk, rather than thermal dust emission.
• The research aims to further explore the starburst-AGN connection and the AGN contribution to the FIR in the nearby universe.
• The study acknowledges the Herschel Space Observatory's role in the research

<summary>
- Myles Hollander expresses his pleasure at returning to Florida State University and his desire to learn more about Myles Samaniego's life and career.
- Hollander recalls his own journey from Carnegie Tech to becoming a math major, influenced by his interest in math and chemistry, and his exposure to statistics through courses taught by Morrie Degroot and Ed Olds.
- Hollander discusses his decision to pursue a Ph.D. at Carnegie Mellon, influenced by his work with the Ladish Forging Company and his interest in statistics, despite the allure of Stanford.
- Hollander shares his high school experiences in Brooklyn, his academic track, and his decision to attend a private college in Pittsburgh, influenced by his parents' commitment to education and his own aspirations.
- He recounts his time at Stanford, his influential cohort of students, and the impact of professors like Lincoln Ellsworth Moses, Rupert Miller, and others on his career.
- Hollander describes his extensive collaborations with colleagues and students, his contributions to nonparametric testing, and his work on the Dirichlet process in Bayesian nonparametrics.
- He reflects on his marriage to Glee Samaniego, their shared interests, and his influence on her career in the extended statistics community.
- Hollander discusses his successful co-authored books on nonparametrics, his teaching style, and his advice on teaching statistics.
- He shares his experiences as department chair, his efforts to broaden the department's focus, and his mentoring of students.
- He reflects on his editorship of the theory and methods section of the Journal of the American Statistical Association and his contributions to the field of nonparametrics.
- Hollander discusses his receipt of the Noether Senior Scholar Award and his hopes for future innovations in Bayesian nonparametrics.
- He talks about his interest in sports, particularly baseball, and his letters to Sports Illustrated.
- He expresses his gratitude for the conversation and the opportunity to reflect on his career and contributions to the field of statistics.
- Hollander and Samaniego thank colleagues for transcribing the conversation.
</summary>

<summary>
- The fundamental group of a real line arrangement whose graph has a unique cycle of length @xmath0 and has no line with more than two multiple points has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
- The fundamental group of a real affine arrangement without parallel lines, whose graph has a unique cycle of length @xmath1 and has no line with more than two multiple points, also has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
- The fundamental group of a real arrangement whose graph is a union of disjoint cycles, with no line having more than two multiple points, has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
</summary>

• The study investigates the generation of non-zero cp violation and tri-bi maximal mixing pattern in a model with @xmath0 symmetry breaking through a single parameter perturbation in the dirac neutrino mass matrix.
• The model predicts non-zero cp violation and deviations from tri-bi maximal mixing pattern, with the mixing angles and mass squared differences varying as functions of two model parameters.
• The model is capable of generating observable cp violation and leptogenesis, with the baryon asymmetry matching the observed WMAP value for a right-handed neutrino mass scale of 8 GeV.
• The model's leptonic mixing matrix phases are correlated, with the low-energy and high-energy phases related to each other.
• The model's parameters are determined by four independent parameters, with the rest being derivable from the model.
• The model's predictions are in agreement with current experimental constraints on neutrino mixing angles, mass squared differences, and the baryon asymmetry of the universe.
• The model's predictions are within the range of the best fit values for the solar and atmospheric mixing angles, and the cp violation parameter is large enough to compensate for the small effect of the small @xmath0.
• The model's predictions are also compatible with the inverted ordering of neutrino mass spectrum.

<summary>
• Organic molecular crystals are promising for nanoscale devices in electronics and optoelectronics, with applications in solar energy and spintronics.
• The electronic structure at the interface between organic and inorganic components is crucial for device performance, affecting charge transfer energies.
• Quasiparticle (qp) descriptions are commonly used to calculate charge transfer energies, but face challenges in capturing the image charge effect.
• Constrained Density Functional Theory (cdft) offers a resource-efficient alternative to qp calculations, avoiding the need for a qp spectrum and focusing on total energy differences.
• The study uses cdft to evaluate charge transfer energies between benzene molecules and graphene, a relevant 2D metal.
• Charge transfer energies decrease as the molecule approaches the graphene sheet, consistent with a classical electrostatic model.
• The presence of structural defects in graphene, like a stone-wales defect, does not significantly alter charge transfer energies.
• Charge transfer energies are affected by the proximity of other benzene molecules, with neighboring molecules slightly reducing the energy levels.
• The study's findings align well with classical electrostatic models, accounting for the finite dielectric constant of graphene.
• The research was supported by the European Research Council and utilized computational resources from the Trinity Center for High Performance Computing and the Irish Center for High End Computing.
• The authors thank Dr. Ivan Rungger and Dr. A.M. Souza for helpful discussions.
• The work is part of the QUEST project.
• The study's findings are published in Physical Review B, with the DOI: 10.1016/j.apsusc.2010.07.069.
</summary>

* The study investigates critical casimir forces ( ccfs) for two colloidal spheres near a homogeneous substrate in a near-critical binary liquid mixture.
* The ccfs are characterized by universal scaling functions, which are studied using mean-field theory and finite element methods.
* The normal and lateral ccfs are found to be sensitive to the colloids' boundary conditions ( bcs) and their proximity to the substrate.
* The lateral ccfs can change sign depending on the bcs of the colloids and the temperature, indicating many-body effects.
* The colloids with the same bcs tend to aggregate laterally, while those with opposite bcs are expected to form three-dimensional clusters.
* The many-body contribution to the normal ccf is found to be attractive for colloids with the same bcs and repulsive for colloids with opposite bcs.
* The many-body contribution to the lateral ccf is always attractive, regardless of the bcs, and is more pronounced when the colloids are close to each other or the substrate.
* The many-body contribution to the normal ccf decays slower than the corresponding contribution to the normal van der Waals force for two atoms close to a surface.
* The many-body contribution to the lateral ccf is repulsive, while the corresponding ccfs are attractive.
* The many-body contribution to the normal ccf is directed towards the substrate for colloids with the same bcs and away from the substrate for colloids with opposite bcs.
* The relative contribution of the many-body ccf to the total force is found to be between 10% and 15%.
* The study compares the ccfs with quantum-electrodynamic casimir forces and van der Waals forces between atoms and a substrate.
* The ccfs exhibit different behaviors compared to the other systems, particularly in the sign and magnitude of the many-body contributions.
* The study suggests that the ccfs could be used to control the assembly of colloidal particles in various configurations.

* The study investigates the hydrogenation of coronene cations in the gas phase using mass spectrometry, revealing that odd hydrogenated states predominate in the mass spectrum, indicating the presence of a barrier for further hydrogenation of odd states.
* The results suggest that superhydrogenated pah cations in the interstellar medium could act as catalysts for hydrogen molecule formation, with barriers decreasing with increasing hydrogenation but not vanishing completely.

<summary>
* The unknowability of wave functions in quantum theory implies a gap between explanation and evidence in atomic clocks used for the second in the SI.
* The operation of atomic clocks involves computer-mediated feedback that steers oscillators toward aiming points, which are constrained by both chosen wave functions and hypothesized spacetime metrics.
* The logical synchronization of clocks in digital communications requires adherence to the principle that signals can only propagate between clocks at distinct phases of their cycles.
* The discipline of logical synchronization emerges from questions about patterns of channels, steering of clocks, and deviations from aiming points, all of which involve hypotheses about signal propagation in relation to spacetime metrics.
* Theoretical models of signal propagation in spacetimes with metrics can be tested against clock readings, which can prompt revisions of the hypothesized metrics.
* The operation of atomic clocks and digital communications involves a feedback loop where unforeseeable detections feed successive computations, impacting probabilities of subsequent outcomes.
* Theoretical models of clocks and communications can be encoded into open machines, which are modified turing machines that communicate with external devices and adjust their operations based on incoming data.
* The operation of open machines involves a fixed point principle that holds onto the phase constraint on channels while hypotheses about signal propagation are subject to revision.
* The number of two-way channels connecting open machines in a static spacetime is independent of curvature, but in a generic spacetime, the number of channels and their echo counts depend on curvature.
* The aiming points for channels and the bit rate for digital communications are constrained by spacetime curvature, with deviations from aiming points requiring predictive steering based on quantum uncertainty.
* The operation of atomic clocks and digital communications involves a logical freedom to make guesses, which allows for the adjustment of clocks and models in response to deviations from aiming points.
* Theoretical models of clocks and communications can be tested against clock readings, which can prompt revisions of the models and the hypothesized spacetime metrics.
* The operation of atomic clocks and digital communications involves a feedback loop where unforeseeable detections feed successive computations, impacting probabilities of subsequent outcomes.
*

<summary>
* Research in wireless ad-hoc networks and wireless sensor networks (WSNs) has escalated, with a focus on low power and low data rate applications for wireless body area networks (WBANs).
* IEEE 802.15.4 standard is targeted for WBANs, supporting two topologies and two modes of operation, with a focus on non-beacon enabled mode using contention-based CSMA/CA protocol.
* The main aim of IEEE 802.15.4 is to provide a low-cost, low-power, and reliable protocol for wireless monitoring of patient health, with three frequency bands, with the 2.4 GHz band being most important.
* The standard defines physical and MAC sub-layer protocols, with the MAC sub-layer playing a crucial role in network performance.
* The MAC sub-layer uses CSMA/CA for channel access, with two main variables for the channel access algorithm: back-off exponent (be) and number of back-offs (nb).
* Performance analysis of IEEE 802.15.4 in WBANs has been conducted, considering various network settings, load, and data rates, with a focus on long-term power consumption.
* An analytical model for the non-beacon enabled mode of IEEE 802.15.4 MAC protocol is provided, allowing evaluation of optimum packet size for maximized transmission success probability.
* Extensive analysis using simulations and real measurements has been performed to investigate unreliability in IEEE 802.15.4, with an emphasis on channel access mechanism and the introduction of a traffic-adaptive MAC protocol (TAMac).
* The performance of IEEE 802.15.4 has been analyzed in terms of load, delay, throughput, and end-to-end delay at varying data rates, with a focus on the impact of acknowledgment (ack) and no-ack conditions.
* The performance of IEEE 802.15.4 improves with higher data rates, with better throughput, lower delay, and end-to-end delay at 250 kbps compared to 20 and 40 kbps.
* Future research will investigate the performance of IEEE 80

<summary>
• Moped is a patented algorithm that compresses data and speeds up likelihood evaluations in astronomical data analysis, particularly when the noise covariance matrix depends on model parameters.
• The algorithm simplifies calculations by transforming data into compressed values with unit variance, reducing the need for matrix inversion.
• Moped's compression can lead to multiple likelihood peaks, which can be problematic for parameter estimation in multimodal or degenerate distributions.
• The authors present scenarios where Moped accurately represents the likelihood function, showing significant runtime improvements, and scenarios where it fails, potentially creating additional peaks in the likelihood function.
• Criteria for Moped's accurate representation of the likelihood include a one-to-one mapping of compressed parameters to original parameters and a lack of degeneracies in the model that could create false peaks.
• A solution to the problem of erroneous peaks is to use multiple fiducial models to generate multiple sets of weighting vectors, averaging the resulting likelihood peaks to maintain true peaks while reducing incorrect ones.
• The authors discuss the implementation of this solution and its effectiveness in increasing the signal-to-noise ratio for parameter recovery.
• The paper is funded by the Gates Cambridge Trust and includes references to previous work on the subject.
• The authors conclude that while Moped can provide substantial computational benefits, it is crucial to verify its accuracy before relying on its results for parameter estimation.
• The paper is part of a larger discussion on the use of Moped in gravitational wave data analysis and other applications.
• The authors suggest that further research and testing are needed to fully understand the limitations and potential of Moped in various scenarios.
• The paper includes figures illustrating the behavior of the original and Moped likelihood functions in different parameter estimation scenarios.
• The authors emphasize the importance of careful application and validation of Moped in practical data analysis.
</summary>

* The cosmological constant problem (CCP) consists of several puzzles: the vacuum energy density being the cosmological constant, large radiative corrections, and the experimental value of the cosmological constant being much smaller than theoretical estimates.
* An effective field theory approach suggests that gravitational corrections of vacuum energy, under the assumption that classical gravitational fields do not effectively couple to a large portion of vacuum energy, can be a candidate for dark energy.
* The zero point energy of gravitons, which do not effectively couple to vacuum energy, could contribute to the dark energy of the universe.
* The study proposes a new perspective on the CCP, suggesting that unknown features of gravity might solve the puzzle, and challenges the construction of a microscopic theory of gravity compatible with these assumptions.

<summary>
* Spectroscopic studies of hyperfine manifolds in alkali metals have been enhanced by high precision experimental techniques, particularly for higher excited states accessible through two-step transitions.
* Two-color modulation transfer spectroscopy is presented as a tool for studying atomic properties of higher excited states, overcoming low signal-to-noise ratio and detector availability issues.
* The technique involves counter-propagating pump and probe lasers, with one laser modulated, to interact with a thermal vapor of atoms.
* The method detects sub-Doppler peaks corresponding to atomic resonances with sidebands, allowing for precise measurements without a thermal population in the intermediate state.
* Theoretical modeling uses a three-level ladder system interacting with modulated lasers, with the system described by a set of coupled equations solved using a floquet basis expansion.
* Experimental setup includes amplitude-modulated and frequency-modulated systems, with the latter allowing for probe laser frequency locking to the atomic resonance.
* The technique has been applied to the @xmath0rb ladder transitions, demonstrating its utility in measuring energy separations and locking laser frequencies.
* The method provides an "in situ" ruler for energy separations and can be extended to other atomic levels.
* Theoretical calculations using relativistic many-body perturbation theory agree well with experimental results for the first @xmath59=1/2 levels.
* The technique's accuracy and reliability make it a promising tool for precision studies of atomic properties in excited states.
* The method has potential to stimulate further experimental and theoretical work in the field of atomic spectroscopy.
* The work was supported by NSF and acknowledges discussions with E. Gomez and P. Barberis.
</summary>

* The physics potential of forward proton tagging at the LHC has attracted attention, particularly for the central exclusive production (cep) process, which could allow direct observation of a particle's quantum numbers and measurement of its mass.
* The fp420 collaboration has proposed installing detectors at 420 m and 220 m from the interaction points at LHC experiments ATLAS and CMS, extending the accessible mass range for cep processes.
* Simulations show that with appropriate detector acceptance and trigger strategies, the cep process of a 120 gev Higgs boson decaying to b-quarks could be observable at the LHC within 3 years, with a significance of at least 1 in the @xmath0 scenario.
* The analysis also suggests that the Higgs boson could be observable in the b-jet channel if the cep channel proves to be observable with the forward detector configurations currently proposed.

• Zero-field Hall effect in chiral @xmath0-wave superconductors (SCs) can arise from vortex dynamics near Kosterlitz-Thouless (KT) transition, offering a new mechanism distinct from intrinsic angular momentum or impurity effects.
• The study generalizes Ahns's vortex dynamics in the chiral @xmath0-wave context, revealing that broken time-reversal symmetry leads to nonzero Hall conductivity without an applied magnetic field.
• Hall conductivity and power dissipation are influenced by the convective ratio, which measures the relative strength between convection and diffusion in the vortex pair dynamics.
• The sign reversal and strong positive peak in Hall conductivity near the KT transition are attributed to the asymmetric angular response of vortex pairs to the driving field, with the convective term in the Fokker-Planck equation playing a crucial role.
• The total conductivity tensor includes contributions from both bound pair and free vortex dynamics, with the bound pair contribution showing divergence in the static limit at low temperatures, while the free vortex contribution shows finite values in the high-temperature limit.
• The analytic expressions for susceptibility matrix elements and conductivity components are derived, showing that the sign and magnitude of these quantities depend on the convective ratio and temperature.
• The study provides insights into the frequency and temperature dependence of Hall conductivity and power dissipation, with implications for understanding the KT transition in SCs and potential experimental observations.

<summary>
• The orion dwarf galaxy's rotation curve ( rc ) suggests a dark matter ( dm) halo with a constant density core rather than a Navarro - Frenk - White ( nfw) profile.
• The galaxy's kinematics are dominated by dark matter, with baryonic matter playing a minor role at all galactocentric radii.
• The orion dwarf's rotation curve is well-fitted by a dark matter halo with a cored density profile, not an nfw profile.
• The Modified Newtonian Dynamics ( mond) framework fails to reproduce the observed kinematics unless significant adjustments to the galaxy's distance and/or gas mass are made.
• The orion dwarf's favorable inclination, regular gas kinematics, small asymmetric drift correction, and large luminous-to-dynamical mass discrepancy make it a decisive benchmark for the mond formalism.
• The galaxy's distance and gas mass are critical for deriving the mond model, and significant adjustments are needed for a satisfactory fit.
• The orion dwarf's characteristics make it a promising target for further detailed studies, including direct distance measurements.
• The authors thank referee Gianfranco Gentile for fruitful comments that improved the presentation of the paper.
• The paper discusses the importance of the orion dwarf galaxy in investigating the nature of dark matter and the evolution of dark matter halos.
• The paper concludes that the orion dwarf galaxy's kinematics unambiguously point towards a cored profile for the dark matter halo.
• The paper emphasizes the need for further studies, including direct distance measurements, to better understand the orion dwarf galaxy and its implications for dark matter research.
</summary>

<summary>
• The trihydrogen dication ( @xmath0 ) is a system of one electron and three protons forming an equilateral triangle and has been intensely studied for its stability.
• Previous studies using variational and single-point calculations did not conclusively demonstrate the instability of @xmath0.
• The present study employs both specialized and standard variational methods to explore the stability of @xmath0.
• The specialized method uses a trial function that interpolates between different physical states of the system, while the standard method uses Gaussian basis functions.
• Numerical calculations were performed for a range of equilateral triangular configurations.
• The results indicate that the total energy does not show a minimum or non-adiabatic irregularities for finite interproton distances.
• The study concludes that the molecular ion @xmath0 does not exist in the equilateral triangular configuration in the born - oppenheimer approximation.
• The research was supported by the Mexican National Council for Science and Technology (CONACYT) and the University of Brussels.
• The authors express gratitude to colleagues for their comments and hospitality during the work.
• The study utilized the molpro quantum chemistry package for calculations.
• The results are presented in tables and figures, with the total energy plotted as a function of the interproton distance.
• The study suggests that the existence of @xmath0 as a metastable state in a magnetic field is a possibility worth further investigation.
• The research contributes to the understanding of the stability of simple coulomb systems and the behavior of trihydrogen dication.
• The findings have implications for the theoretical understanding of simple coulomb systems and the potential existence of exotic states under specific conditions.
• The study highlights the importance of using advanced computational methods to investigate the properties of simple coulomb systems.
• The research provides a comprehensive analysis of the stability of the trihydrogen dication, contributing to the broader field of quantum chemistry and molecular physics.
• The study's findings have potential applications in understanding the behavior of simple coulomb systems and their potential applications in various fields.

* recent investigations reveal a complex relationship between galaxy properties and their environments, with clustering correlating with both star formation history and luminosity.
* studies show that galaxy environment is independent of surface brightness and concentration at fixed color and luminosity, suggesting color and luminosity measures of star formation history have a more fundamental relationship with environment.
* the dependence of galaxy clustering on scale is unclear, with some studies finding environment important at small scales and others at large scales.
* our study finds that the dependence of mean environment on color persists to lower luminosities, extending previous findings by about two magnitudes.
* we find that the overdensity on large scales does not relate to the recent star formation history of galaxies, suggesting that only the masses of the host halos affect galaxy star formation.
* our results support the "halo model" of galaxy formation and encourage pursuit of semi-analytic models that depend only on the properties of the host halo.
* our study highlights the importance of considering the properties of the host dark matter halos in understanding galaxy formation.
* our findings have implications for the physics of galaxy formation and the pursuit of models that consider only the properties of the host halo.
* our study suggests that the local galaxy density may not adequately represent the environment affecting galaxy formation.
* our results encourage the "halo model" description of galaxy formation and the pursuit of models that consider only the properties of the host halo.
* our study underscores the importance of taking care when using low signal-to-noise quantities to measure galaxy environments.
* our findings support the notion that only the masses of the host halos of galaxies are strongly affecting the star formation of galaxies.

<summary>
• Transverse spin fluctuations are gapless low-energy excitations in antiferromagnetic systems with continuous spin-rotational symmetry, influencing macroscopic properties like long-range order and temperature dependence of the order parameter.
• In the strong coupling limit, spin fluctuations significantly reduce the antiferromagnetic order parameter in two dimensions to nearly half of the classical value.
• A new method is presented for evaluating transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections in terms of magnon mode energies and spectral functions obtained in the random phase approximation (RPA).
• The method is applicable across the entire range of interaction strength and illustrated with three cases: the half-filled Hubbard model, spin vacancies in the strong coupling limit, and low-@xmath3 impurities in the strong coupling limit.
• The RPA approach interpolates between weak and strong coupling limits and agrees with spin-wave theory (SWT) results as the interaction strength approaches the strong coupling limit.
• The method uses a convenient way to perform the frequency integral for spin correlations and is validated by the agreement with SWT results for the half-filled Hubbard model.
• The method is extended to finite lattices to study defects like spin vacancies and impurities, showing that spin fluctuation corrections are sharply enhanced by spin vacancies but strongly suppressed by low-@xmath3 impurities.
• The overall reduction in the averaged spin fluctuation correction due to low-@xmath3 impurities compensates for the enhancement due to spin vacancies, resulting in nearly no loss of antiferromagnetic order.
• The method is applicable to other situations involving defects in antiferromagnets, such as disorder and disorder-induced local moments.
• The paper acknowledges support from the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation and conversations with D. Vollhardt and M. Ulmke.
• The method provides a systematic way to evaluate quantum corrections to sublattice magnetization in antiferromagnetic systems, offering insights into the effects of defects and impurities on magnetic order.
• The paper concludes that the RPA method offers a comprehensive approach to understanding the role of quantum spin fluctuations in antiferromagnetic materials.

* The study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory, particularly in cosmology, has gained attention due to its implications for understanding inflation and reheating in the early universe.
* The paper presents a formalism to address the dynamics of coupled scalar fields with time-varying interactions, focusing on renormalization and the effects of fluctuations on mean field evolution.
* The formalism is applied to two-field models, including a supersymmetric hybrid inflationary model, revealing that fluctuations significantly alter the trajectory of zero modes and the production of particles, suggesting a need to reevaluate certain predictions of supersymmetric hybrid inflationary models.

* The paper presents an extension of the Higgs triplet model (HTM) that naturally incorporates a dark matter (DM) candidate and explains tiny neutrino masses without heavy triplet fields.
* The model introduces a new @xmath0-odd scalar field @xmath1 with an unbroken @xmath2 symmetry, which at the tree level forbids the @xmath3-term but allows the @xmath4-term at the one-loop level.
* The DM candidate is the @xmath5 scalar, and the neutrino masses arise from the @xmath6-term at the one-loop level, naturally suppressed by the loop mechanism.
* The model predicts small neutrino masses and a light DM candidate, consistent with experimental constraints from neutrino oscillations and direct DM searches.
* The model also predicts lepton flavor violation (LFV) processes, which can be probed in collider experiments, providing a potential signature for the model.
* The model's scalar sector includes a real @xmath7 singlet scalar, a @xmath8 doublet scalar, and a @xmath9 doublet scalar, with the latter two being odd under the @xmath2 symmetry.
* The model's scalar potential and mass formulae are provided in the appendix, and the scalar fields' properties are summarized in a table.
* The paper discusses the implications of the model for collider physics and LFV processes, suggesting that the model could be tested in future experiments.
* The authors conclude that the model offers a viable extension of the HTM that naturally explains the smallness of neutrino masses and provides a candidate for dark matter, while also being consistent with current experimental constraints.
* The work was supported by grants from the Japanese Science Society and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

<summary>
* The introduction of quantum technologies necessitates a new telecommunications infrastructure capable of handling quantum properties.
* Quantum communication devices can tolerate imperfections if classical post-processing is applied, but a minimal quantum requirement is to avoid measure and prepare channels.
* Quantum throughput can be quantified by comparing input and output quantum correlations in a 'prepare and measure' scenario, avoiding the need for bipartite states.
* A strong quantum channel preserves most quantum correlations, and this throughput can be used to characterize device suitability for quantum tasks.
* The paper presents a method to estimate effective entanglement in optical systems using homodyne measurements and knowledge of initial state preparation.
* The method involves estimating parameters of the most significant subspace formed by conditional states and constructing a projected density matrix.
* The minimal entanglement compatible with the projected matrix is found using semidefinite programming, with constraints derived from the initial state and homodyne results.
* The method's effectiveness is demonstrated using data from an optical channel, showing bounds on effective entanglement for various loss and noise parameters.
* The bounds become less accurate as noise increases, due to the estimation procedure and the bounds used for maximal eigenvalues and overlaps.
* The method is particularly useful for characterizing optical devices with low noise, and can complement entanglement verification methods.
* The paper suggests that the method could be extended to use more than two eigenstates for a more accurate projection and to overcome the complexity of higher-dimensional truncations.
* The method provides a practical tool for understanding the quantum nature of optical devices and their ability to preserve quantum correlations.
* The paper includes appendices with technical details and derivations of the bounds used in the method.
</summary>

• The study of dipole moments of elementary particles has significantly advanced our understanding of subatomic physics, leading to the discovery of spin, radiative corrections, and the quark structure of baryons.
• The muon anomaly, measured to 0.5 ppm, is sensitive to new physics at the TeV scale, and the muon anomaly measurement has been used to set the best determination of the fine-structure constant.
• The muon anomaly measurement is sensitive to hadronic vacuum polarization contributions, and the hadronic contribution to the muon anomaly is difficult to calculate directly from QCD, but can be related to cross-section measurements.
• The search for permanent electric and magnetic dipole moments (EDMs) of the muon is crucial for probing new physics beyond the Standard Model, with susy models predicting enhanced EDMs for the muon.

<summary>
• A new optomechanical system design featuring a microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide is presented, enabling the study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling.
• The reactive coupling originates from the mechanical motion-dependent extrinsic losses of the disk resonator and phase-dependent gradient forces.
• The system's nonlinear response to pump probe fields is examined, revealing reactive-coupling-induced normal mode splitting in output fields.
• Without reactive coupling, no normal mode splitting occurs in the output fields, but it appears with reactive coupling.
• The normal mode splitting in output fields is solely due to reactive coupling, and the peak separation increases with increasing pump power.
• The reactive coupling can also cause four-wave mixing, generating an anti-Stokes field.
• The system parameters, such as cavity decay rate and waveguide displacement, influence the strength of reactive coupling and the resulting normal mode splitting.
• The reactive coupling can lead to the generation of an anti-Stokes field, with the maximum gain depending on the system parameters.
• The study demonstrates the potential of reactive coupling in optomechanical systems for various applications, including quantum effects at the macroscopic scale.
• The findings contribute to the understanding of optomechanical systems and pave the way for future research in this field.
• The paper builds upon previous works that focused on dispersive coupling in optomechanical devices.
• The research was conducted using a silicon waveguide and a microdisk resonator with specific dimensions and properties.
• The results have implications for the development of optomechanical devices and their applications in various fields.
• The study was published in Physical Review Letters and Nature Photonics.
</summary>

* A study on the dynamics of transverse magnetization in an integrable quantum Ising chain reveals that the system, when prepared with an initial state inducing inhomogeneity, does not relax to a homogeneous magnetization state even after infinite time, contrary to classical expectations.
* The transverse magnetization exhibits oscillatory behavior with an algebraically decaying envelope, and the decay exponent is independent of the external field strength.
* The frequency of the characteristic oscillation changes monotonically with the external field in the ferromagnetic phase and becomes independent in the paramagnetic phase, coinciding with the system's quantum phase transition from ordered to disordered phase.
* The study suggests that the presence of odd-occupation states in the initial configuration plays a crucial role in the dynamics, leading to persistent inhomogeneity and non-thermal behavior, which may prompt further investigation into the behavior of non-local observables and the dynamics of non-integrable systems starting from such inhomogeneity.

* The study of QCD at finite baryon density is crucial for understanding the structure of compact stars and conditions near the core of collapsing stars.
* Gapless color superconducting phases, such as g2sc and gcfl, can exist in the color superconducting phase diagram at moderate baryon density, but exhibit chromomagnetic instabilities due to mismatch between fermi surfaces of pairing quarks.
* The g2sc phase shows a paramagnetic response to an external baryon current, indicating the spontaneous generation of a baryon current that breaks rotational symmetry, resembling the one-plane wave loff state.
* The g2sc phase also exhibits a spontaneous generation of five pseudo nambu-goldstone currents, covering the gluon phase and the one-plane wave loff state, and revealing the instability driven by mismatch in the system.

* The paper discusses the complexities of identifying the true equilibrium state in two-dimensional (2D) melting phase transition simulations, particularly for systems with repulsive screened Coulomb (yukawa) interactions.
* It is shown that equilibration times are crucial for observing the hexatic phase, with short-range positional and quasi-long-range orientational order appearing in short simulations but vanishing in longer, true equilibrium simulations.
* The study reveals that equilibration times for different quantities of interest vary significantly, with velocity distribution equilibration being the fastest, followed by configurational temperature, and then long-range correlation functions.
* The paper suggests that earlier numerical studies may have been misled by kinetic bottlenecks, identifying the hexatic phase metastably instead of the true equilibrium configuration.

• The Kepler mission has discovered over 4100 planetary candidates, revealing that small, super-Earth to mini-Neptune sized planets are common, with a sharp transition in planet types occurring near a radius of 1.5 Earth radii.
• Accurate planetary radii are crucial for understanding planetary structures and occurrence rates, but only about half of the Kepler candidate stars have been observed, with the assumption that all are single stars.
• Recent studies suggest a non-negligible fraction of Kepler host stars may be multiple stars, which can affect the observed transit depths and derived planetary radii.
• Without spectroscopic or high-resolution imaging observations to vet companions, the observed planetary radii are systematically too small, leading to an overestimation of planet bulk densities.
• Radial velocity and high-resolution imaging vetting can significantly reduce the mean correction factors for planetary radii, with single epoch high-resolution imaging being particularly effective for K2 and TESS targets due to their closer proximity to Earth.
• The presence of undetected stellar companions can lead to an overestimation of the occurrence rates of Earth-sized planets by up to 15-20% and an underestimation of giant planets by up to 30%.
• A comprehensive understanding of planetary occurrence rates requires accounting for the presence of stellar companions and the limits of observational vetting methods.
